subsubsection.title: Use the definition of root
subsubsection.p: Because ~(\sqrt{a})(\sqrt{a})=a,~ it is also true that ~\dfrac{a}{\sqrt{a}}= \sqrt{a}.

statement.p:
Simplify. Do not use a calculator!
\left(\sqrt{7}\right)\left(\sqrt{7}\right)
\sqrt{n}(\sqrt{n})

solution.p:
By the definition of square root, \sqrt{a} is a number whose square is a.
\left(\sqrt{7}\right)\left(\sqrt{7}\right)=7
\sqrt{n}(\sqrt{n})=n

statement.p:
Simplify. Do not use a calculator!
\left(\sqrt[3]{5}\right)^3
\left(\sqrt[3]{4}\right)\left(\sqrt[3]{4}\right)\left(\sqrt[3]{4}\right)

solution.p:
By the definition of cube root, \sqrt[3]{a} is a number whose cube is a.
\left(\sqrt[3]{5}\right)^3=5
\left(\sqrt[3]{4}\right)\left(\sqrt[3]{4}\right)\left(\sqrt[3]{4}\right)=4

subsubsection.title: Irrational numbers
subsubsection.p: Rational numbers are the integers and common fractions; we can represent them precisely in decimal form. But the best we can do for an irrational number is to write an approximate decimal form by rounding.

ol.li: Irrational: ~\sqrt{6}~ is not the quotient of two integers.

li.p: Rational: ~\dfrac{-5}{3}~ is the quotient of two integers.

solution.p:
Use a calculator to evaluate.

Enter (-) 2 \boxed{\sqrt{}}~ 21 3 ENTER and round to three decimal places: ~-3.055
Enter 2 MATH 4 5 ENTER and round to three decimal places: ~3.710

subsubsection.title: Using exponents and roots
subsubsection.p: Be careful to avoid tempting but false operations with exponents and roots.

li.p: The first statement is not correct. There is no law that says (a+b)^n is equivalent to a^n+b^n, so (1+r)^4 is not equivalent to 1^4+r^4 or 1+r^4.
However, it is true that (ab)^n = a^nb^n, so in particular the second statement is true: ~~(ab^t)^3 = a^3(b^t)^3 = a^3b^{3t}
The first statement is correct. If we start with (2^{1/5})^t, we can apply the third law, (a^m)^n = a^{mn}, to find (2^{1/5})^t = 2^{(1/5)t} = 2^{t/5}.
In the second statement, 6.8 is not raised to power t, so we cannot multiply 6.8 times 10.

assemblage.title: Properties of Radicals
assemblage.p: In general, it is not true that \sqrt[n]{a+b} is equivalent to \sqrt[n]{a}+\sqrt[n]{b}, or that \sqrt[n]{a-b} is equivalent to \sqrt[n]{a}-\sqrt[n]{b}.

li.p: The first statement is incorrect. There is no property that says ~\sqrt[n]{a+b} = \sqrt[n]{a} + \sqrt[n]{b}.
However, it is true that ~\sqrt[n]{a}~ \sqrt[n]{b} = \sqrt[n]{ab}~, so the second statement is correct.
The first statement is incorrect, because \dfrac{x+y}{x} is not equivalent to y.
The second statement is correct, because ~\sqrt{x+y}~\sqrt{x+y} = x+y.
